claim: Among posts authored by the user 'slashnick' on the Codebase Community, the post with the highest answer count has ID 351.
extra_info: most answers count refers to MAX(AnswerCount); post by slashnick refers to DisplayName = 'slashnick';
reasoning: User 'slashnick' has only one post in the database, with Id=351. Since it is the only post, it trivially has the highest AnswerCount (even though the value is NULL). The claim that the post with the highest answer count has ID 351 is supported by the data.

CREATE TABLE posts
(
    Id                    INTEGER          not null UNIQUE
        primary key,
    PostTypeId            INTEGER          null,
    AcceptedAnswerId      INTEGER          null,
    CreaionDate           DATETIME     null,
    Score                 INTEGER          null,
    ViewCount             INTEGER          null,
    Body                  TEXT     null,
    OwnerUserId           INTEGER          null,
    LasActivityDate       DATETIME     null,
    Title                 TEXT null,
    Tags                  TEXT null,
    AnswerCount           INTEGER          null,
    CommentCount          INTEGER          null,
    FavoriteCount         INTEGER          null,
    LastEditorUserId      INTEGER          null,
    LastEditDate          DATETIME     null,
    CommunityOwnedDate    DATETIME    null,
    ParentId              INTEGER          null,
    ClosedDate            DATETIME     null,
    OwnerDisplayName      TEXT null,
    LastEditorDisplayName TEXT null,
        foreign key (LastEditorUserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (OwnerUserId) references users (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade,
        foreign key (ParentId) references posts (Id)
            on update cascade on delete cascade
);

content.text: Now let me query for the post by 'slashnick' with the highest AnswerCount:

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT p.Id, p.AnswerCount FROM posts p JOIN users u ON p.OwnerUserId = u.Id WHERE u.DisplayName = 'slashnick' ORDER BY p.AnswerCount DESC LIMIT 5;"
input.description: Find slashnick's post with highest AnswerCount

content.text: It seems the AnswerCount might be NULL. Let me check further:

input.command: sqlite3 -header "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT p.Id, p.AnswerCount, p.Title, p.PostTypeId FROM posts p JOIN users u ON p.OwnerUserId = u.Id WHERE u.DisplayName = 'slashnick' ORDER BY p.AnswerCount DESC;"
input.description: Get all posts by slashnick with details

content.text: Slashnick has only one post (Id=351), and it's a PostTypeId=2 (an answer), which typically doesn't have an AnswerCount. But since this is the only post, it trivially has the highest AnswerCount (even if NULL). Let me also check if AnswerCount is NULL or 0:

input.command: sqlite3 -header "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/codebase_community.sqlite" "SELECT p.Id, p.AnswerCount, CASE WHEN p.AnswerCount IS NULL THEN 'NULL' ELSE CAST(p.AnswerCount AS TEXT) END as AC_check FROM posts p JOIN users u ON p.OwnerUserId = u.Id WHERE u.DisplayName = 'slashnick';"

content.text:
Slashnick has only one post (Id=351), and its AnswerCount is NULL. Since it's the only post by this user, it is trivially the post with the "highest" answer count. The claim states that among posts authored by 'slashnick', the post with the highest answer count has ID 351. Since there is only one post and its ID is 351, this is supported by the data.
